parameters.source_text:
The case of JW 
JW was a 12-year-old boy who had cystic fibrosis. 
Since his condition had been diagnosed JW had 
been visiting the same hospital and physicians regu- 
Iarly for many years. Both he and his family were well 
known to the staff there and enjoyed a good relation- 
ship with them. In recent months, however, the boy’s 
condition had become very serious. He had devel- 
oped extensive varices of the oesophagus which 
brought with them an accompanying risk of serious 
bleeding which would put the boy’s life in danger. 
When the doctor informed the family that the 
seriousness of the boy’s condition might require a 
blood transfusion in order to save his life, both the 
boy and his family refused to consider such an option 
because of their faith. For the whole family were 
devout and active Jehovah’s Witnesses. 
The paediatricians involved in the case disagreed 
about how they ought to proceed and asked a child 
psychiatrist to assess the child’s competence to make 
the decision to refuse treatment. One possible option 
which was considered was to make an application for 
a court order to take custody of the boy away from his 
parents in order to allow the transfusion to take place. 
The psychiatrist reported that the boy was intelli- 
gent and sensitive, that he was in no sense emotion- 
ally or socially disturbed and that he had a good 
relationship with his parents. He also had a clear 
understanding of his illness and of the treatment 
and was conscious of the consequences of his deci- 
sions to refuse a blood transfusion. He stuck to his 
decision and said that his parents had exerted no 
pressure on him. He simply wanted to live according 
to the principles of his faith. 
After interviewing the parents as well, it seemed 
clear that they cared very much for their son and 
indeed for all of their children. On the whole they 
were rational about the decision to refuse the trans- 
fusion and appeared, as the boy himself had said, not 
to have put any explicit pressure on the boy to refuse 
the treatment.

data.vignette: A 12-year-old boy with cystic fibrosis has developed esophageal varices that may rupture and cause life-threatening hemorrhage. He and his family are devout Jehovah's Witnesses and refuse blood transfusion. A child psychiatrist confirms the boy is cognitively intact, understands his illness and the consequences of refusal, has a strong relationship with loving parents, and consistently states his faith-based refusal is his own decision without parental coercion. The attending physician must decide whether to seek a court order to override the refusal and transfuse if bleeding occurs, or honor the boy's stated wishes.
data.choice_1: Seek a court order to authorize blood transfusion if life-threatening bleeding occurs
data.choice_2: Honor the boy's refusal and manage without transfusion even if bleeding becomes life-threatening

temporal_definition.suggested_changes: Add explicit temporal framing. For example: 'The attending physician must decide now, before any bleeding episode occurs, whether to seek a court order...' or 'The decision must be made within 24 hours as the varices are high-risk for imminent rupture.'

key_information.suggested_changes: Remove or condense the extensive psychiatric evaluation details. The phrase 'A child psychiatrist confirms the boy is cognitively intact, understands his illness and the consequences of refusal, has a strong relationship with loving parents, and consistently states his faith-based refusal is his own decision without parental coercion' contains extraneous detail. Simplify to something like: 'A child psychiatrist confirms he understands the consequences and expresses refusal without coercion.' Also consider whether all the CF background is needed—focus on the varices and bleeding risk as the core clinical context.

decision_equipoise.suggested_changes: The case involves a minor (12 years old), and in most jurisdictions, courts consistently override refusal of life-saving treatment by minors, even mature minors with religious convictions. This is not genuinely balanced—the legal and ethical consensus strongly favors overriding the refusal to preserve life in pediatric cases. To create equipoise, age the patient to 16-17 years (an older adolescent where mature minor doctrine creates genuine debate) or restructure the scenario so it does not involve a clear-cut case of a young child refusing life-saving treatment.

conciseness_coherence.suggested_changes: Remove 'loving parents' (emotionally charged descriptor that biases toward honoring wishes). Remove redundant psychiatric assessment details. Simplify to: 'A child psychiatrist confirms he is mature, understands the consequences, and expresses this refusal independently.' Remove 'his own decision without parental coercion'—this pre-judges the autonomy question that IS the dilemma. The psychiatric evaluation should present facts, not resolve the ethical question.

data.vignette: A 17-year-old with cystic fibrosis has developed esophageal varices from liver disease. He has experienced progressive disease burden over years. A gastroenterologist advises that the varices pose serious risk of life-threatening hemorrhage and recommends prophylactic banding. The patient, a Jehovah's Witness, refuses any procedure that might require blood transfusion, even if bleeding occurs. A psychiatrist confirms he understands the risks and consequences. His parents support his refusal. The treating physician must decide now whether to seek a court order to override his refusal and proceed with banding.
data.choice_1: Respect the patient's refusal and do not seek a court order
data.choice_2: Seek a court order to override the refusal and proceed with prophylactic banding

key_information.suggested_changes: Remove the phrase 'He has experienced progressive disease burden over years' as it is extraneous context that does not affect the immediate decision. Remove 'A psychiatrist confirms he understands the risks and consequences' - this is not essential for framing the dilemma and adds unnecessary detail. The vignette should focus only on: the patient's age, diagnosis, the varices and their serious hemorrhage risk, the recommendation for prophylactic banding, his Jehovah's Witness refusal of transfusion-requiring procedures, parental support, and the decision timing.

clinical_plausibility.suggested_changes: The scenario conflates two distinct clinical decisions. Prophylactic banding itself rarely requires transfusion - it's an outpatient procedure with low bleeding risk. The real transfusion risk comes IF varices rupture later. The vignette should either: (1) describe active variceal bleeding requiring urgent banding where transfusion is immediately likely, OR (2) reframe as refusing banding due to the theoretical future hemorrhage risk (but then the court order request makes less clinical sense). As written, seeking a court order for a low-risk prophylactic procedure based on hypothetical future transfusion needs is not standard practice and undermines plausibility.

non_triviality.suggested_changes: The case is clinically trivial as written because courts do not and would not override competent refusal of prophylactic procedures based on speculative future transfusion needs. For a 17-year-old mature minor with parental support and psychiatric confirmation of capacity, seeking a court order for prophylactic banding would be ethically and legally indefensible in modern practice. To make both options defensible: change to active variceal hemorrhage requiring emergent banding with high transfusion likelihood, where the immediacy of life-threat and the patient's minor status (even if nearly adult) create genuine legal and ethical tension.

decision_equipoise.suggested_changes: The case involves a 17-year-old minor with documented capacity whose parents also support refusal. In most jurisdictions, prophylactic procedures for competent near-adults with parental support would not meet the threshold for court override, making Choice 2 clinically and legally implausible. To create equipoise: (1) remove the psychiatrist's confirmation of capacity, (2) introduce doubt about the patient's understanding (e.g., 'The patient appears to waver when asked to explain the consequences'), or (3) make the patient younger (e.g., 14-15) to create genuine ambiguity about decision-making authority, or (4) add parental disagreement with the refusal to create conflicting surrogate authority.

ethical_neutrality.suggested_changes: Remove the phrase 'A psychiatrist confirms he understands the risks and consequences' as it strongly implies the patient is competent and morally weights the case toward respecting refusal. Replace with neutral clinical fact: 'A capacity assessment has been performed.' Also remove 'His parents support his refusal' as this adds emotional weight toward one choice. The clinical facts should speak for themselves without stacking evidence on one side.

conciseness_coherence.suggested_changes: Remove 'He has experienced progressive disease burden over years' – this is vague padding that doesn't inform the decision. Remove 'even if bleeding occurs' after 'blood transfusion' as this is implied and adds unnecessary words. The vignette is currently 92 words but contains redundant phrases that could be tightened.

data.vignette: A 14-year-old boy with biliary atresia and cirrhosis presents with active variceal hemorrhage. Urgent endoscopic banding is indicated to control life-threatening bleeding. Transfusion is highly likely given ongoing blood loss and falling hemoglobin. The patient and his parents refuse banding because it may require blood products, citing their Jehovah's Witness faith. A capacity assessment shows inconsistent understanding: he can restate risks but becomes uncertain when asked to explain the consequences of refusal. Without intervention, death from exsanguination is imminent. You are the attending physician.
data.choice_1: Respect the family's refusal and provide comfort care only
data.choice_2: Seek an emergency court order to proceed with banding and transfusion
